title: Activity-based protein profiling of a surfactin-producing nonribosomal peptide synthetase in Bacillus subtilis

Step-by-step method details
Synthesis of compound 5
Timing: 2 days
This method outlines the preparation of compound 5 (Figure S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1720-Mmc1.pdf]. Synthetic route to Asp-AMS-BPyne, related to steps 1–11).
Weigh 50 mg (0.090 mmol) of compound 4 (Konno et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]) in a 10 mL dried two-neck round-bottom flask containing a magnetic stirring bar under Ar.
Add 1 mL of dry N,N-dimethylformamide to the flask.
Add 46 mg (0.12 mmol) of Boc-Asp(OtBu)-OSu and 88 mg (0.27 mmol) of cesium carbonate to the flask.
Stir the solution at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 1 h.
Filter the reaction mixture through a pad of Celite.
Dilute the filtrate with 10 mL of ethyl acetate.
Wash the organic layer with 5% aqueous citric acid (20 mL), saturated sodium bicarbonate (20 mL), and saturated sodium chloride (3 × 10 mL) using a separatory funnel.
Dry the organic layer with sodium sulfate and filter to remove the sodium sulfate.
Remove the volatile material using a rotary evaporator under reduced pressure to obtain a crude product.
Purify the crude product using silica gel column chromatography (6/94 to 9/91 methanol/chloroform) to obtain compound 5 (64 mg, 0.077 mmol, yield 86%, Rf = 0.62 [methanol/chloroform/H2O = 67/25/8]) as a colorless solid.
Characterize the product using 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and ESI-MS. (See the expected outcomes[href=https://www.wicell.org#expected-outcomes] section).
Pause point: At this point, the product can be stored at a temperature between −20 and −80°C for several months.
Synthesis of compound 6
Timing: 3 days
This method outlines the preparation of compound 6 (Figure S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1720-Mmc1.pdf]. Synthetic route to Asp-AMS-BPyne, related to steps 12–19).
Weigh 59 mg (0.071 mmol) of compound 5 in a 10 mL dried two-neck round-bottom flask containing a magnetic stirring bar under Ar.
Add 4 mL of methanol to the flask.

Add 6 mg of palladium 10% on carbon to the flask.
Stir the solution at room temperature (20°C–25°C) under a H2 atmosphere for 18 h.
Filter the reaction mixture through a pad of Celite.
Remove the volatile material using a rotary evaporator under reduced pressure to obtain a crude product.
Purify the crude product using silica gel column chromatography (methanol/chloroform = 14/86) to obtain compound 6 (40 mg, 0.050 mmol, yield 70%, Rf = 0.50 [methanol/chloroform/H2O = 67/25/8]) as a white solid.
Characterize the product using 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and ESI-MS. (See the expected outcomes[href=https://www.wicell.org#expected-outcomes] section).
Pause point: At this point, the product can be stored at a temperature between −20 and −80°C for several months.
Synthesis of compound 7
Timing: 2 days
This method outlines the preparation of compound 7 (Figure S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1720-Mmc1.pdf]. Synthetic route to Asp-AMS-BPyne, related to steps 20–34).
Weigh 18 mg (0.044 mmol) of compound 6 in a 10 mL dried two-neck round-bottom flask containing a magnetic stirring bar under Ar.
Add 1 mL of dry N,N-dimethylformamide to the flask.
Add 6.7 mg (0.044 mmol) of 1-hydroxybenzotriazole and 7.7 mg (0.044 mmol) of 1-Ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl) carbodiimide hydrochloride to the flask.
After stirring at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 10 min, add 30 mg (0.037 mmol) of compound 8 (Konno et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]) to the flask.
Stir the solution at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 3 h.
Extract the reaction mixture with ethyl acetate (3 × 100 mL) using a separatory funnel to obtain an organic layer.
Wash the organic layer with saturated sodium chloride (3 × 300 mL).
Dry the organic layer with sodium sulfate and filter to remove the sodium sulfate.
Remove the volatile material using a rotary evaporator under reduced pressure to obtain a crude product.
Dilute the reaction mixture with 10 mL of ethyl acetate.

Wash the organic layer with 5% aqueous citric acid (20 mL), saturated sodium bicarbonate (20 mL), and saturated sodium chloride (3 × 10 mL) using a separatory funnel.
Dry the organic layer with sodium sulfate and filter to remove the sodium sulfate.
Remove the volatile material using a rotary evaporator under reduced pressure to obtain a crude product.
Purify the crude product using silica gel column chromatography (9/91 to 17/83 methanol/chloroform) to obtain compound 7 (35 mg, 0.029 mmol, yield 79%, Rf = 0.53 [methanol/chloroform/H2O = 67/25/8]) as a white solid.
Characterize the product using 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and ESI-MS. (See the expected outcomes[href=https://www.wicell.org#expected-outcomes] section).
Pause point: At this point, the product can be stored at a temperature between −20 and −80°C for several months.
Synthesis of Asp-AMS-BPyne
Timing: 3 days
This method outlines the preparation of Asp-AMS-BPyne (Figure S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1720-Mmc1.pdf]. Synthetic route to Asp-AMS-BPyne, related to steps 35–40).
Weigh 30 mg (0.025 mmol) of compound 7 in a 10 mL single-neck round-bottom flask containing a magnetic stirring bar.
Add 2 mL of a 4:1 (v/v) mixture of trifluoroacetic acid and H2O to the flask.
Stir the solution at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 10 h.
Remove the volatile material using a rotary evaporator under reduced pressure to obtain a crude product.
Purify the crude product using silica gel column chromatography (20/80 to 33/67 methanol/chloroform) to obtain Asp-AMS-BPyne (20 mg, 0.022 mmol, yield 87%, Rf = 0.11 [methanol/chloroform/H2O = 67/25/8]) as a white solid.
Characterize the product using 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and ESI-MS. (See the expected outcomes[href=https://www.wicell.org#expected-outcomes] section).
Pause point: At this point, the product can be stored at a temperature between −20 and −80°C for several months.
Synthesis of compound 11
Timing: 2 days

This method outlines the preparation of compound 11 (Figure S2[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1720-Mmc1.pdf]. Synthetic route to Asp-AMS, related to steps 41–48).
Weigh 50 mg (0.13 mmol) of compound 10 (Ishikawa and Kakeya, 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]) in a 10 mL single-neck round-bottom flask containing a magnetic stirring bar.
Add 2 mL of dry N,N-dimethylformamide to the flask.
Add 46 mg (0.12 mmol) of Boc-Asp(OtBu)-OSu and 127 mg (0.39 mmol) of cesium carbonate to the flask.
Stir the solution at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 3 h.
Filter the reaction mixture through a pad of Celite.
Remove the volatile material using a rotary evaporator under reduced pressure to obtain a crude product.
Purify the crude product using silica gel column chromatography (6/94 methanol/chloroform) to obtain compound 11 (50 mg, 0.076 mmol, yield 58%, Rf = 0.51 [methanol/chloroform/H2O = 67/25/8]) as a white solid.
Characterize the product using 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and ESI-MS. (See the expected outcomes[href=https://www.wicell.org#expected-outcomes] section).
Pause point: At this point, the product can be stored at a temperature between −20 and −80°C for several months.
Synthesis of Asp-AMS
Timing: 3 days
This method outlines the preparation of Asp-AMS (Figure S2[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1720-Mmc1.pdf]. Synthetic route to Asp-AMS, related to steps 49–54).
Weigh 40 mg (0.053 mmol) of compound 11 in a 10 mL single-neck round-bottom flask containing a magnetic stirring bar.
Add 2 mL of a 4:1 (v/v) mixture of trifluoroacetic acid and H2O to the flask.
Stir the solution at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 6 h.
Remove the volatile material using a rotary evaporator under reduced pressure to obtain a crude product.
Purify the crude product using silica gel column chromatography (33/67 methanol/chloroform to methanol) to obtain compound Asp-AMS (26 mg, 0.056 mmol, quant., Rf = 0.01 [methanol/chloroform/H2O = 67/25/8]) as a white solid.

Characterize the product using 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy and ESI-MS. (See the expected outcomes[href=https://www.wicell.org#expected-outcomes] section).
Pause point: At this point, the product can be stored at a temperature between −20 and −80°C for several months.
Sample preparation for in vitro labeling studies
Timing: 2 h
This method outlines the preparation of samples for proteomics analysis.
Grow B. subtilis ATCC 21332 at 30°C with 250 rpm shaking in 250 mL cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton II broth in a 1000-mL baffled flask.
Harvest the bacterial cells after 12 h (OD600 = 0.71) by centrifugation (10 min, 10,000 × g, 4°C).
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Wash twice with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) (-), resuspend in 10 mL of PBS (-), and aliquot in 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes.
Centrifuge the solution (10 min, 10,000 × g, 4°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Remove the maximum possible volume of PBS using a pipette.
Store the pellets at −80°C until use.
Pause point: At this point, the pellets can be stored at −80°C for several months.
Resuspend the frozen cell pellets in cold T1 solution with protease inhibitor cocktail solution (200–500 μL).
Add a 10 mg/mL lysozyme solution to the resuspended cells to a final concentration of 0.2 mg/mL.
Incubate the mixture on ice for 30 min with gentle shaking (Shaker SR-1, AS ONE Corporation) (100 rpm).
Transfer the mixture to a medium size constant temperature incubator shaker (TAITEC Corporation).
Incubate at 37°C for 30 min with gentle shaking (100 rpm).
Critical: Large NRPS proteins were found to be particularly sensitive to mechanical cell disruption processes, and it is therefore necessary to treat the bacterial cells gently to obtain the intracellular proteins (Augenstein et al., 1974[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]).
Centrifuge the mixture for 10 min at 15,000 × g at 4°C and collect the supernatant.

Critical: If viscosity is observed in bacterial cell lysates due to DNA content after step 66, add DNase I (1 U), incubate on ice for 5 min, centrifuge the mixture for 10 min at 15,000 × g at 4°C, and collect the supernatant.
Determine protein concentration using Bradford assay in a 96-well plate.
Prepare 10 μL serial dilutions (2×) of sample in T1 solution and pipet 2 μL of each solution into separate wells.
For BSA protein standard, prepare 10 μL serial dilutions (2×) with protein concentrations 2, 1, 0.5, 0.25, and 0.13 mg/mL in T1 solution and pipet 2 μL of each solution into separate wells.
Add 198 μL of protein assay CBB solution and incubate for 10 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Read absorbance at 595 nm using a Multiscan FC plate reader.
Normalize protein concentration to 2.0–3.0 mg/mL.
Pause point: Lysate can be aliquoted and frozen at −80°C in 10% glycerol for at least 1 month.
In vitro labeling studies
Timing: 2–3 h
This method outlines the labeling of an endogenous SrfAB-NRPS in vitro.
For labeling studies, treat the protein extracts (45 μL, 2.0–3.0 mg/mL) with DMSO (0.5 μL) and Asp-AMS-BPyne (0.5 μL of 100 μM stock in DMSO, final concentration: 1 μM) for 10 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
For inhibition studies, treat the protein extracts (45 μL, 2.0–3.0 mg/mL) with Asp-AMS (0.5 μL of 10 mM stock in DMSO, final concentration: 100 μM) for 10 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C) and subsequently incubate the mixture with Asp-AMS-BPyne (0.5 μL of 100 μM stock in DMSO, final concentration: 1 μM) for 10 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Critical: A 96-well plate is used to obtain reproducible photo-labeling.
Critical: The final DMSO concentration is kept at 2.2% (v/v).

Perform UV irradiation of the 96-well plate using a UVP Crosslinker (Analytik Jena) (8 W, 365 nm, on ice, Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1720-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Apparatus for UV irradiation
CRITICAL: Wear proper personal protective equipment, such as UV goggles, lab gloves, and lab coat, when performing UV irradiation.
Critical: To obtain reproducible, efficient, and specific photoaffinity labeling, the following distance and time of labeling are used: 1 cm distance from the top of a 96-well plate and 5 min.
Critical: Removing the 96-well plate lid will provide more efficient irradiation and, therefore, higher labeling efficiency.
Perform CuAAC chemistry reaction by adding 4 μL of in vitro CuAAC click chemistry mix into each well. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
Note: CuSO4, TBTA, TCEP, and 5/6-TAMRA-PEG3-azide are added to provide final concentrations of 1 mM, 100 μM, 1 mM, and 100 μM, respectively.
Incubate each sample at room temperature (20°C–25°C) in the dark for 1 h.
Take 40 μL of each sample for SDS-PAGE and in-gel fluorescence analysis.
Add 10 μL of reducing 5× SDS-loading buffer to each sample, mix by pipetting up and down, and heat at 95°C for 5 min.
Pause point: Samples can be stored at −80°C for up to one week. In this case, perform the heating step again (95°C for 5 min) before loading on gel.
Place an SDS-PAGE (6%) gel in a clean plastic electrophoresis chamber and corresponding gel holder.
Prepare 1× SDS-PAGE running buffer (200 mL).
Fill the inner portion between the gel and the gel holder with the 1× running buffer.
Pour the remaining 1× running buffer into the outer chamber.
Load 20 μL of each sample on the gel.

Run the gel at 20 mA until the dye front migrates into the running gel (∼10 min), and increase to 40 mA until the dye front reaches the bottom of the gel (∼45 min).
Remove the gel from the apparatus and remove the spacers and glass plates.
Place the gel into a small tray.
Add ∼100 mL Milli-Q water into the tray and wash the gel for 5 min with gentle shaking (50 rpm).
Scan the gel with a Typhoon 9410 Gel and Blot Imager (GE Healthcare) with 532 nm laser excitation and 580 nm emission using standard procedures (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Pour off the Milli-Q water, add ∼50 mL fixing solution into the tray, and fix the gel for 30 min with gentle shaking (50 rpm).
Pour off the fixing solution, add ∼50 mL staining solution into the tray, and stain the gel with Colloidal Coomassie Blue Stain for > 6 h with gentle shaking (50 rpm).
Pour off the staining solution and add ∼100 mL Milli-Q water into the tray.
Destain the gel with gentle shaking (50 rpm) until the gel is visibly destained (> 2 h).

Add 400 μL of PBS to the bacterial cells and resuspend by pipetting.

Treat the bacterial cells with DMSO (0.4 μL) or Asp-AMS-BPyne (0.4 μL of 10 mM stock in DMSO, final concentration: 10 μM) for 60 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).

Fluorescence imaging studies in living bacterial cells
Timing: 5–6 h
This method outlines the fluorescence imaging of an endogenous SrfAB-NRPS in living bacterial cells.
Grow B. subtilis ATCC 21332 at 30°C with 200 rpm shaking in 250 mL iron-enriched minimal salt medium in a 1000-mL baffled flask.
Transfer the bacterial cells harvested from the culture (16 h, OD600 = 0.92) to a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Wash twice with 1 mL of PBS at room temperature (20°C–25°C).

Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Add 1 mL of PBS to the bacterial cells and resuspend by pipetting.
Treat the bacterial cells with DMSO (1 μL) or Asp-AMS-BPyne (1 μL of 10 mM stock in DMSO, final concentration: 10 μM) for 60 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Critical: The final DMSO concentration is kept at 0.1% (v/v).
Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Wash twice with 1 mL of PBS.
Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Add 100 μL of PBS to the bacterial cells and resuspend by pipetting.
Transfer the bacterial cells to a 96-well plate.
Critical: A 96-well plate is used for obtaining reproducible photo-labeling.
Perform UV irradiation for the 96-well plate using a UVP Crosslinker (Analytik Jena) (8 W, 365 nm, on ice, Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
Critical: To obtain reproducible, efficient, and specific photoaffinity labeling, the following distance and time of labeling are used: 1 cm distance from the top of a 96-well plate and 5 min.
Transfer the bacterial cells to a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Add 400 μL of 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS to the bacterial cells and resuspend by pipetting.
After 10 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C), centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Wash twice with 1 mL of PBS.
Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.

Pause point: The bacterial cells can be resuspended in ethanol solution I and stored at −30°C for up to 24 h. Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells and wash twice with 1 mL of PBS prior to step 157.
Add 200 μL of triton-X 100 solution to the bacterial cells and resuspend by pipetting.
After 15 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C), centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Perform the in-cell CuAAC chemistry reaction. Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Add 1.25 μL of 20 mM CuSO4 solution, 2.5 μL of 50 mM THPTA solution, and 0.3 μL of 20 mM 5/6-TAMRA-PEG3-azide solution to a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube (total volume: 4.05 μL).
Incubate the mixture in the dark at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 3 min.
Add 12.5 μL of 100 mM sodium ascorbate, 12.5 μL of 100 mM aminoguanidine, and 221 μL of PBS to a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube (total volume: 246 μL).
Add the 151a solution to the 151c solution (total volume: 4.05 μL + 246 μL = 250.05 μL).
Add 221 μL of the 151d solution to the bacterial cell pellet.
Critical: When preparing the CuAAC chemistry master mix, add reagents in the order that is listed in step 160 to ensure proper copper reduction and formation of a complex between copper and ligand.
Note: CuSO4, THPTA, 5/6-TAMRA-PEG3-azide, sodium ascorbate, and aminoguanidine are added to provide final concentrations of 100 μM, 500 μM, 25 μM, 5 mM, and 5 mM, respectively.
Note: Make enough master mix for at least one additional sample than necessary, to safeguard against volume loss during pipetting.
Incubate each sample at room temperature (20°C–25°C) in the dark for 1 h.

Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Wash three times with 1 mL of PBS.
Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Wash once with 1 mL of ethanol solution I.
Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Wash once with 1 mL of ethanol solution II.
Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.
Wash once with 1 mL of ethanol solution III. Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Centrifuge (10 min, 10,000 × g, 20°C) to pellet the bacterial cells.

Add 100 μL of PBS to the bacterial cell pellets and resuspend by pipetting.
Acquire images using a fluorescence microscope.
